Description: Egyptian terracotta model of a Gaulish shield. A fragmentary model of an oval Gaulish shield, with a bound edge and an oval boss, from which a central spine emerges above and below; the boss is held by a horizontal plate, expanding to concave ends that embrace a large stud. At the back, which is unmodelled and concave, a vertical strap-handle was applied, but is broken away. Pressed into a one-piece mould. Brown Nile silt with a darkbrown core, and abundant fine gold mica and small white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: Locally made at Site 95, a terracotta workshop noted in 1885 at the eastern edge of the city. BM1886,0401.1444, 1886,0401.1451-2, 1886,0401.1537-40, 1886,0401.1574 and 1888,0601.108 were found together at a terracottas workshop (Petrie 1886: 45). Petrie dates this workshop to about the end of the 1st century AD, Bailey 3rd to 2nd century BC. For a shield with fittings very close to this (Stary 1981: 61) after a stele from Sidon of the 2nd century BC. These stelai may be Ptolemaic of the late 3rd century BC or Seleucid of after 160 BC (Sekunda 1995: 19). The two stelai which have shields like this are of Dioskourides and of Salmas (Sekunda 1995: colour photos 3 and 2). Compare also the shields held by a cleruch (BM1888,0601.97, Bailey 2008: no.3550) and a Gaulish mercenary (BM1994,1001.2, Bailey 2008: no.3552), both probably of the 3rd century BC. 'Site 95' written on the object in pencil. Site 95 is the terracotta workshop, found by sebakhin in 1885, at the eastern edge of the city. Sekunda, N. 1995. ‘Seleucid and Ptolemaic Reformed Armies 168-145 BC, vol. II: The Ptolemaic Army.’ Stockport. Stary, P.F. 1981. in Germania 59, Beilage 6.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3300)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DF.09) (Phase 1)
Condition: One end and much of one side is lost.
